The **Old Course at St Andrews** is considered the oldest [golf
course](/wiki/Golf_course "Golf course") in the world,[2][3] a public course
over common land in [St Andrews](/wiki/St_Andrews "St Andrews"),
[Fife](/wiki/Fife "Fife"), [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland"). It is held
in trust by The St Andrews Links Trust under an act of
[Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom "Parliament of the United
Kingdom"). [The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St
Andrews](/wiki/The_Royal_and_Ancient_Golf_Club_of_St_Andrews "The Royal and
Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews") club house sits adjacent to the first
[tee](/wiki/Tee "Tee"), although it is but one of many clubs that have playing
privileges on the course, along with the general public.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Course_at_St_Andrews&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

The Old Course at St Andrews is considered by many to be the "home of golf"
because the sport was first played on the Links at St Andrews in the early
15th century.[4] Golf was becoming increasingly popular in Scotland until in
1457, when [James II of Scotland](/wiki/James_II_of_Scotland "James II of
Scotland") banned golf because he felt that young men were playing too much
golf instead of practising their archery.[4] The ban was upheld by the
following kings of Scotland until 1502, when [King James
IV](/wiki/King_James_IV_of_Scotland "King James IV of Scotland") became a
golfer himself and removed the ban.[5]

###
Governance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Course_at_St_Andrews&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Governance")]

In 1552, [Archbishop John
Hamilton](/wiki/John_Hamilton_\(archbishop_of_St_Andrews\) "John Hamilton
\(archbishop of St Andrews\)") gave the townspeople of St. Andrews the right
to play on the links. In 1754, 22 noblemen, professors, and landowners founded
the Society of St Andrews Golfers. This society would eventually become the
precursor to the [Royal and Ancient](/wiki/Royal_and_Ancient "Royal and
Ancient") which is the governing body for golf everywhere outside of the
[United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") and [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico
"Mexico").[6] St Andrews Links had a scare when they went bankrupt in 1797.[6]
The Town Council of St. Andrews decided to allow rabbit farming on the golf
course to challenge golf for popularity. Twenty years of legal battling
between the golfers and rabbit farmers ended in 1821 when a local landowner
and golfer named James Cheape of [Strathtyrum](/wiki/Strathtyrum
"Strathtyrum") bought the land and is credited with saving the links for
golf.[4] The course evolved without the help of any one architect for many
years, though notable contributions to its design were made by Daw Anderson in
the 1850s and Old Tom Morris (1865–1908), who designed the 1st and 18th holes.
Originally, it was played over the same set of fairways out and back to the
same holes. As interest in the game increased, groups of golfers would often
be playing the same hole, but going in different directions.[4]

### Influence on modern
golf[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Course_at_St_Andrews&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Influence on modern golf")]

The Old Course was pivotal to the development of how the game is played today.
For instance, in 1764, the course had 22 holes. The members would play the
same hole going out and in with the exception of the 11th and 22nd holes. The
members decided that the first four and last four holes on the course were too
short and should be combined into four total holes (two in and two out). St
Andrews then had 18 holes and that was how the standard of 18 holes was
created.[7] Around 1863, [Old Tom Morris](/wiki/Old_Tom_Morris "Old Tom
Morris") had the 1st green separated from the 17th green, producing the
current 18-hole layout with seven double greens and four single greens. The
Old Course is home of [The Open Championship](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The
Open Championship"), the oldest of golf's major championships. The Old Course
has hosted this major 29 times since 1873, most recently in 2015. The 29 [Open
Championships](/wiki/Open_Championship "Open Championship") that the Old
Course has hosted is more than any other course, and The Open is currently
played there every five years.

### Old Course and Bobby
Jones[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Course_at_St_Andrews&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Old Course and Bobby Jones")]

[Bobby Jones](/wiki/Bobby_Jones_\(golfer\) "Bobby Jones \(golfer\)") (who
later founded [Augusta National](/wiki/Augusta_National "Augusta National"))
first played St Andrews in the 1921 [Open
Championship](/wiki/Open_Championship "Open Championship"). During the third
round, he infamously hit his ball into a bunker on the 11th hole. After he
took four swings at the ball and still could not get out, after losing his
temper, he continued the round, but did not turn in score card, thus
disqualifying himself. However, he did continue to play in the fourth round.
Six years later, when the Open Championship returned to St Andrews, Jones also
returned. Not only did he win, he also became the first amateur to win back-
to-back Open Championships. He won wire-to-wire, shooting a 285 (7-under-par),
which was the lowest score at either a [U.S. Open](/wiki/U.S._Open_\(golf\)
"U.S. Open \(golf\)") or Open Championship at the time. He ended up winning
the tournament by a decisive six strokes.

In 1930, Jones returned to St Andrews for the [British
Amateur](/wiki/The_Amateur_Championship "The Amateur Championship").[8] He
won, beating [Roger Wethered](/wiki/Roger_Wethered "Roger Wethered") by a
score of 7 and 6 in the final match. He subsequently won the other three
majors, making him the only man in the history of the sport to win the [Grand
Slam](/wiki/Grand_Slam_\(golf\) "Grand Slam \(golf\)"). Jones went on to fall
in love with the Old Course for the rest of his life. Years later, he said "If
I had to select one course upon which to play the match of my life, I should
have selected the Old Course." In 1958 the town of St Andrews gave Jones the
[key to the city](/wiki/Freedom_of_the_City#Key_to_the_City "Freedom of the
City"); he was only the second American to receive the honour (after [Benjamin
Franklin](/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin "Benjamin Franklin") in 1759). After he
received the key, he said "I could take out of my life everything but my
experiences here in St. Andrews and I would still have had a rich and full
life."[9]

##
Features[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Course_at_St_Andrews&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Features")]

"I'm very sentimental and the place gets to me every time I go there. St
Andrews was always where I wanted to finish my major career."

—[Jack Nicklaus](/wiki/Jack_Nicklaus "Jack Nicklaus") on finishing his career
at St Andrews, 2005.[10]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Bridge_Photo.jpg/220px-
Bridge_Photo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bridge_Photo.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bridge_Photo.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Swilcan Bridge](/wiki/Swilcan_Bridge "Swilcan Bridge") is one of the most
iconic attractions in golf

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Bridge_over_the_Swilken_burn.jpg/220px-
Bridge_over_the_Swilken_burn.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bridge_over_the_Swilken_burn.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bridge_over_the_Swilken_burn.jpg "Enlarge")

The 18th hole towards the clubhouse of the
[R&A](/wiki/Royal_and_Ancient_Golf_Club_of_St_Andrews "Royal and Ancient Golf
Club of St Andrews") in 2006.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Old_Course_1891.png/220px-
Old_Course_1891.png)](/wiki/File:Old_Course_1891.png)

[](/wiki/File:Old_Course_1891.png "Enlarge")

A largely unchanged view in 1891.

One of the unique features of the Old Course are the large double greens.
Seven greens are shared by two holes each, with hole numbers adding up to 18
(2nd paired with 16th, 3rd with 15th, all the way up to 8th and 10th). The
[Swilcan Bridge](/wiki/Swilcan_Bridge "Swilcan Bridge"), spanning the first
and 18th holes, has become a famous icon for golf in the world.[11] Everyone
who plays the 18th hole walks over this 700-year-old bridge, and many iconic
pictures of the farewells of the most iconic golfers in history have been
taken on this bridge.[12] A life-size stone replica of the Bridge is situated
at the [World Golf Hall of Fame](/wiki/World_Golf_Hall_of_Fame "World Golf
Hall of Fame") museum in [St. Augustine, Florida](/wiki/St._Augustine,_Florida
"St. Augustine, Florida").[12] Only the 1st, 9th, 17th and 18th holes have
their own greens. Another unique feature is that the course can be played in
either direction, clockwise or anti-clockwise. Along with that, the Old Course
has 112 bunkers which are all individually named and have their own unique
story and history behind them. The two most famous are the 10 ft deep "Hell
Bunker"[13] on the 14th hole, and the "Road Bunker" on the 17th hole.
Countless professional golfers have seen their dreams of winning the [Open
Championship](/wiki/Open_Championship "Open Championship") squandered by
hitting their balls into those bunkers.

The Old Course is also home of _The Road Hole_ , the par-4 17th, one of the
world's most famous golf holes. Among its unique features are:

  * Players using the back tees cannot see where their tee shots land. This is not unusual except that they must take aim over a corner of replica railway sheds which lie beyond the out of bounds wall. The original sheds were torn down when the rail line running next to the course closed, and after several Opens were played without the tee shot being blind, replicas of the sheds were created in preparation for the 1984 Open.
  * Other than [rough](/wiki/Rough_\(golf\) "Rough \(golf\)"), the primary hazard in front of the green is a sand trap known as the "Road Bunker."
  * Over the back of the green, hazards include a [tarmac](/wiki/Tarmac "Tarmac") roadway, as well as an old stone wall. Both are in play; a wayward shot can lead a player to take their next stroke off the roadway or to hit the face of the wall and take their chances with the ensuing bounce.

The general method of play today is counterclockwise, although clockwise play
has been permitted on one day each year in recent years, and for several
special one off events since. Originally, the course was reversed every week
in order to let the grass recover better. One other unusual thing about the
Old Course is that it is closed on Sundays to let the course rest.[14] On some
Sundays, the course turns into a park for all the townspeople who come out to
stroll, picnic and otherwise enjoy the grounds. As a general rule, Sunday play
is allowed on the course on only four occasions:

  * The final day of the [Dunhill Links Championship](/wiki/Dunhill_Links_Championship "Dunhill Links Championship"), an annual event on the [European Tour](/wiki/European_Tour "European Tour").
  * The final day of any R&A sanctioned Open Championships – [men](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The Open Championship") and [women](/wiki/Women%27s_British_Open "Women's British Open"), and the [men over 50](/wiki/Senior_Open_Championship "Senior Open Championship") when it is held at the Old Course; this happens roughly once every five years for the men; the women's championship began its turn on the rotation in 2007, and the over-50 championship began in 2018.
  * The final day of two top amateur events, the [St Andrews Links Trophy](/wiki/St_Andrews_Links_Trophy "St Andrews Links Trophy") and the St Rule Trophy.

Sunday play may also occur when the Old Course hosts other major events; for
example, when it hosted the [Curtis Cup](/wiki/Curtis_Cup "Curtis Cup") in
2008.

While winning the Open Championship is a crowning achievement for any golfer,
a win at St Andrews is considered particularly important due to the course's
long tradition. Past winners at St Andrews include [Tiger
Woods](/wiki/Tiger_Woods "Tiger Woods") (twice), [Louis
Oosthuizen](/wiki/Louis_Oosthuizen "Louis Oosthuizen"), [John
Daly](/wiki/John_Daly_\(golfer\) "John Daly \(golfer\)"), [Zach
Johnson](/wiki/Zach_Johnson "Zach Johnson") (first Monday finish since 1988),
[Nick Faldo](/wiki/Nick_Faldo "Nick Faldo"), [Seve
Ballesteros](/wiki/Seve_Ballesteros "Seve Ballesteros"), [Jack
Nicklaus](/wiki/Jack_Nicklaus "Jack Nicklaus") (twice), [Tony
Lema](/wiki/Tony_Lema "Tony Lema"), [Kel Nagle](/wiki/Kel_Nagle "Kel Nagle"),
[Bobby Locke](/wiki/Bobby_Locke "Bobby Locke"), [Peter
Thomson](/wiki/Peter_Thomson_\(golfer\) "Peter Thomson \(golfer\)"), [Sam
Snead](/wiki/Sam_Snead "Sam Snead"), [Dick
Burton](/wiki/Dick_Burton_\(golfer\) "Dick Burton \(golfer\)"), [Denny
Shute](/wiki/Denny_Shute "Denny Shute"), [Bobby
Jones](/wiki/Bobby_Jones_\(golfer\) "Bobby Jones \(golfer\)"), [Jock
Hutchison](/wiki/Jock_Hutchison "Jock Hutchison"), [James
Braid](/wiki/James_Braid_\(golfer\) "James Braid \(golfer\)") (twice), [John
Henry Taylor](/wiki/John_Henry_Taylor "John Henry Taylor") (twice), [Hugh
Kirkaldy](/wiki/Hugh_Kirkaldy "Hugh Kirkaldy"), [Jack
Burns](/wiki/Jack_Burns_\(golfer\) "Jack Burns \(golfer\)"), [Bob
Martin](/wiki/Bob_Martin_\(golfer\) "Bob Martin \(golfer\)") (twice), [Jamie
Anderson](/wiki/Jamie_Anderson_\(golfer\) "Jamie Anderson \(golfer\)"), [Tom
Kidd](/wiki/Tom_Kidd_\(golfer\) "Tom Kidd \(golfer\)"), [Lorena
Ochoa](/wiki/Lorena_Ochoa "Lorena Ochoa"), and most recently [Stacy
Lewis](/wiki/Stacy_Lewis "Stacy Lewis") at the [2013 Women's British
Open](/wiki/2013_Women%27s_British_Open "2013 Women's British Open").

In 2005 the Old Course was ranked as the greatest golf course outside the
United States, by _[Golf Digest](/wiki/Golf_Digest "Golf Digest")_.

Since 1990, the Old Course has been unique on the Open roster in holding the
Championship every five years. However, this sequence has been broken with the
announcement that the 2020 Championship will be at [Royal St.
George's](/wiki/Royal_St._George%27s "Royal St. George's"). The reason for
this is that the 2021 Championship will be the 150th, and is expected to be
played on the Old Course although no official announcement has yet been made.

## The Open

"Edit section: The Open Championship")]

has been staged at the Old Course at St Andrews 29 times. The following is a
list of the champions:

Instead of three rounds of 12 holes, there were two rounds of 18. Kidd won £11.

**[1927](/wiki/1927_Open_Championship "1927 Open Championship")** | [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Flag_of_the_United_States_%281912-1959%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States_%281912-1959%29.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Bobby Jones (a)](/wiki/Bobby_Jones_\(golfer\) "Bobby Jones \(golfer\)") 2nd | 68 | 72 | 73 | 72 | **285** (−3) | This win marked Bobby Jones' first Open championship win at St Andrews, his second straight Open Championship, fourth professional major, and his 7th career major (he was a three-time winner of the U.S. Amateur). As an amateur, Jones received no prize money. [Aubrey Boomer](/wiki/Aubrey_Boomer "Aubrey Boomer") and [Fred Robson](/wiki/Fred_Robson "Fred Robson") finished in a tie for second, and the winners and second place share of £75 for first place and £50 for second place were combined and divided into two, so each player earned 62 pounds and 10 shillings.  
**[1933](/wiki/1933_Open_Championship "1933 Open Championship")** | [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Flag_of_the_United_States_%281912-1959%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States_%281912-1959%29.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Denny Shute](/wiki/Denny_Shute "Denny Shute") | 73 | 73 | 73 | 73 | **292** (+4) PO | Shute won the Open title by five strokes in a playoff against Craig Wood. Leo Diegel could have joined them but he whiffed a putt on the 72nd hole, finishing one shot off the lead. The winners share was £100.  
**[1939](/wiki/1939_Open_Championship "1939 Open Championship")** | [![England](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/be/Flag_of_England.svg/23px-Flag_of_England.svg.png)](/wiki/England "England") [Dick Burton](/wiki/Dick_Burton_\(golfer\) "Dick Burton \(golfer\)") | 70 | 72 | 77 | 71 | **290** (−2) | The 1939 Open was the last Open until 1946 because of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). The [Royal Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force "Royal Air Force") used the fairways of the Old Course as runways. Burton held the Claret Jug the longest (7 years), until the tournament resumed in [1946](/wiki/1946_Open_Championship "1946 Open Championship"), also at St Andrews. The winners share was £100.  
**[1946](/wiki/1946_Open_Championship "1946 Open Championship")** | [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Flag_of_the_United_States_%281912-1959%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States_%281912-1959%29.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Sam Snead](/wiki/Sam_Snead "Sam Snead") | 71 | 70 | 74 | 75 | **290** (−2) | Even though Sam Snead won the first Open Championship to be played since [1939](/wiki/1939_Open_Championship "1939 Open Championship"), he still lost money because of the high travel expenses; his winner's share was £150. When taking the train into St Andrews, Sam Snead is quoted for looking out of the window and saying "Say, that looks like an old abandoned golf course" about the Old Course.  
**[1955](/wiki/1955_Open_Championship "1955 Open Championship")** | [![Australia](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Flag_of_Australia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Australia.svg.png)](/wiki/Australia "Australia") [Peter Thomson](/wiki/Peter_Thomson_\(golfer\) "Peter Thomson \(golfer\)") 2nd | 71 | 68 | 70 | 72 | **281** (−7) | This was the second of Thomson's three straight Open titles, and five overall. His winner's share was £1,000.  
**[1957](/wiki/1957_Open_Championship "1957 Open Championship")** | [![South Africa](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Flag_of_South_Africa_%281928-1994%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_South_Africa_%281928-1994%29.svg.png)](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") [Bobby Locke](/wiki/Bobby_Locke "Bobby Locke") 4th | 69 | 72 | 68 | 70 | **279** (−9) | Between 1949 and 1957, Locke won the Open title four times. He survived a possible disqualification when he marked his ball on the 72nd green, and played his ball without replacing his ball mark. The R&A decided that because he had a three shot lead, and he didn't gain an advantage, that in the spirit of the game, he should not be disqualified. The winner's share was £1,000.  
**[1960](/wiki/1960_Open_Championship "1960 Open Championship")** | [![Australia](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Flag_of_Australia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Australia.svg.png)](/wiki/Australia "Australia") [Kel Nagle](/wiki/Kel_Nagle "Kel Nagle") | 69 | 67 | 71 | 71 | **278** (−10) | This was the 100th anniversary of the Open Championship, although due to wars it wasn't the 100th Open Championship to be played. [Arnold Palmer](/wiki/Arnold_Palmer "Arnold Palmer") finished second and is credited with returning the Open to the eyes of Americans. The winner's share was £1,250.  
**[1964](/wiki/1964_Open_Championship "1964 Open Championship")** | [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Tony Lema](/wiki/Tony_Lema "Tony Lema") | 73 | 68 | 68 | 70 | **279** (−9) | From 1962 to 1966, Lema won 12 times on tour, but this was his only major. He beat Jack Nicklaus by five strokes, and his winner's share was £1,500. Tragically, Lema and his pregnant wife were killed in a plane crash two years later.  
**[1970](/wiki/1970_Open_Championship "1970 Open Championship")** | [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Jack Nicklaus](/wiki/Jack_Nicklaus "Jack Nicklaus") 2nd | 68 | 69 | 73 | 73 | **283** (−5)PO | Doug Sanders missed a tough two and a half-foot (0.75 m) putt on the 72nd hole, bogeyed, and ended up tied with Nicklaus. The playoff the next day came down to 18th hole and Nicklaus birdied to win; it was his second Open title and eighth overall major; the winner's share was £5,250.  
**[1978](/wiki/1978_Open_Championship "1978 Open Championship")** | [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Jack Nicklaus](/wiki/Jack_Nicklaus "Jack Nicklaus") 3rd | 71 | 72 | 69 | 69 | **281** (−7) | Nicklaus completed the career Grand Slam (winning all four majors in your career at least once) for the third time making it his third Open Championship. The winner's share was £12,500  
**[1984](/wiki/1984_Open_Championship "1984 Open Championship")** | [![Spain](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png)](/wiki/Spain "Spain") [Seve Ballesteros](/wiki/Seve_Ballesteros "Seve Ballesteros") 2nd | 69 | 68 | 70 | 69 | **276** (−12) | The leaderboard for the final day was full of the best golfers in the world at the time. Ballesteros beat Bernhard Langer, Tom Watson, Fred Couples, Lanny Wadkins, Nick Faldo, and Greg Norman to make an epic final round at St Andrews. Ballesteros birdied the 72nd hole to win by two, and his fist pump is an iconic image to this day. His winner's share was £50,000.  
**[1990](/wiki/1990_Open_Championship "1990 Open Championship")** | [![England](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/be/Flag_of_England.svg/23px-Flag_of_England.svg.png)](/wiki/England "England") [Nick Faldo](/wiki/Nick_Faldo "Nick Faldo") 2nd | 67 | 65 | 67 | 71 | **270** (−18) | Faldo set the Open championship scoring record shooting 18 under par, winning his second major of the year, his second Open Championship and his fourth overall major. The winner's share was £85,000.  
**[1995](/wiki/1995_Open_Championship "1995 Open Championship")** | [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [John Daly](/wiki/John_Daly_\(golfer\) "John Daly \(golfer\)") | 67 | 71 | 73 | 71 | **282** (−6)PO | This Open was significant because it was the first that Tiger Woods played in, and the last that Arnold Palmer played in, getting to have his farewell at St Andrews. John Daly beat Costantino Rocca in a four-hole playoff to win the Open title and £125,000.  
**[2000](/wiki/2000_Open_Championship "2000 Open Championship")** | [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Tiger Woods](/wiki/Tiger_Woods "Tiger Woods") 1st | 67 | 66 | 67 | 69 | **269** (−19) | Winning the 2000 British Open was Tiger Woods' second consecutive major championship, completing the career grand slam; he would win the next two major championships as well for four consecutive major victories - the "Tiger Slam". He didn't hit a single bunker the entire tournament, won by eight strokes, and set the new Open Championship scoring record with 19 under par. The winner's share was £500,000.  
**[2005](/wiki/2005_Open_Championship "2005 Open Championship")** | [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Tiger Woods](/wiki/Tiger_Woods "Tiger Woods") 2nd | 66 | 67 | 71 | 70 | **274** (−14) | This was Jack Nicklaus's last Open Championship and like Arnold Palmer, he finished on the Old Course. This was also Tiger's 10th major championship and the fourth one he had won by five or more strokes, and the winner's share was £720,000.  
**[2010](/wiki/2010_Open_Championship "2010 Open Championship")** | [![South Africa](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Flag_of_South_Africa.svg/23px-Flag_of_South_Africa.svg.png)](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") [Louis Oosthuizen](/wiki/Louis_Oosthuizen "Louis Oosthuizen") | 65 | 67 | 69 | 71 | **272** (−16) | On the 150th anniversary of [the first Open Championship](/wiki/1860_Open_Championship "1860 Open Championship"), Oosthuizen played consistently well, winning the Open title by shooting a 16 under par 272 and winning by seven strokes. [Rory McIlroy](/wiki/Rory_McIlroy "Rory McIlroy") shot a 63 in the opening round and the winner's share was £850,000.  
**[2015](/wiki/2015_Open_Championship "2015 Open Championship")** | [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Zach Johnson](/wiki/Zach_Johnson "Zach Johnson") | 66 | 71 | 70 | 66 | **273** (−15)PO | In the 144th playing of the Open Championship, Zach Johnson emerged from a three-man playoff to win the tournament. Tom Watson was given a special exemption by the R & A in order that he could finish his Open career at the Old Course. The tournament finished on Monday due to the extremely high winds that arose during Saturday's round. Johnson defeated [Louis Oosthuizen](/wiki/Louis_Oosthuizen "Louis Oosthuizen") and [Marc Leishman](/wiki/Marc_Leishman "Marc Leishman") in a four-hole playoff.  
  
  * Note: Multiple winners of The Open Championship have superscript ordinal designating which in their respective careers.
  * (a) denotes [amateur](/wiki/Amateur "Amateur")
